data.description: Nearly 13,000 men died on these grounds, a site that became infamous even before the Civil War ended. Their burial grounds became Andersonville National Cemetery, where veterans continue to be buried today. This place, where tens of thousands suffered captivity so others could be free, is also home to the National Prisoner of War Museum and serves as a memorial to all American prisoners of war.
data.directionsInfo: Andersonville National Historic Site is located in southwest Georgia. The park is approximately 12 miles north of Americus and 11 miles south of Montezuma on GA-49.

operatingHours.description: The National Prisoner of War Museum is open daily from 9:30 am to 4:30 pm. Park grounds, including the National Cemetery, are open daily from 8:00 AM to 5:00 PM. On Thanksgiving Day, Christmas Day, and New Year's Day, the National Prisoner of War Museum and prison site are closed but Andersonville National Cemetery is open from 8:00 AM to 5:00 PM pending staff availability.
operatingHours.name: Andersonville National Historic Site Operating Hours

images.title: Historic Site of Camp Sumter Civil War Military Prison at Andersonville
images.altText: A cannon sits out in front of a replica of part of the wooden stockade walls once at Andersonville
images.caption: Camp Sumter Military Prison, known as Andersonville, was the deadliest ground of the Civil War. Nearly 13,000 American soldiers died here.

images.title: The National Prisoner of War Museum
images.altText: Large brick museum with a sign in front reading "The National Prisoner of War Museum"
images.caption: The National Prisoner of War Museum

images.title: Summer of 1865 at Andersonville Photo by A.J. Riddle
images.altText: A historic photo of thousands of emaciated Union soldiers held prisoner in 1865
images.caption: Over 32,000 Union soldiers languished at Andersonville in August 1865 when this photo was taken by A.J. Riddle.

images.title: Memorial Courtyard
images.altText: stone statue stands with his arms stretched forward. Two large stone walls sit behind him.
images.caption: Memorial Courtyard

images.title: Andersonville National Cemetery
images.altText: Fog rests on a stone monument of a Civil War soldier standing among hundreds of graves.
images.caption: The site where the nearly 13,000 Union soldiers who died at Andersonville, designated as a National Cemetery in 1865, is still an active cemetery. Nearly 21,000 American military veterans rest here in honor.

images.title: New York Monument Sunset
images.altText: large stone monument with a pink and purple sunset in the background.
images.caption: New York Monument Sunset

images.title: Magnolia Trees of Andersonville National Cemetery
images.altText: green leaves with a large white flower in the center.
images.caption: Magnolia Trees of Andersonville National Cemetery

data.weatherInfo: Summer temperatures reach highs in the 80s-90s and high humidity. Winter temperatures tend to be in the 40s and below. Snow can occur but is rare. Average annual precipitation is 46.24 inches and is fairly evenly distributed throughout the year. The National Prisoner of War Museum is maintained at a cool temperature to help preserve artifacts; dressing in layers is recommended.
data.name: Andersonville

data.description: The Appalachian Trail is a 2,190+ mile long public footpath that traverses the scenic, wooded, pastoral, wild, and culturally resonant lands of the Appalachian Mountains. Conceived in 1921, built by private citizens, and completed in 1937, today the trail is managed by the National Park Service, US Forest Service, Appalachian Trail Conservancy, numerous state agencies and thousands of volunteers.
data.directionsInfo: There are many points of access along the Appalachian Trail, whether it is by car, train, bus or plane. For more detailed directions, please refer to the "Directions" section of our park webpage.

operatingHours.description:
In general, the Appalachian Trail is open year-round. The northern terminus at Mount Katahdin in Maine is within Baxter State Park, which may be closed in winter months, depending on weather conditions. 
Particular sections of the Trail, and less-developed roads accessing the Trail, may be closed temporarily for a number of reasons, but otherwise the trail is open.
operatingHours.name: Appalachian National Scenic Trail

images.title: McAfee Knob
images.altText: Silhouette of a man with backpack standing on McAfee Knob at sunset with mountains in the distance.
images.caption: McAfee Knob is one of the most popular locations along the A.T. to take photographs.

images.title: Appalachian Trail
images.altText: The Appalachian Trail runs across a mountain ridge line with views to the horizon of mountain range.
images.caption: Crossing into thirteen states, hikers experience a variety of scenery along the way.

images.title: The Infamous White Blaze of the A.T.
images.altText: A white blaze marks a tree in the foreground, with a man and child walking away on the wooded trail.
images.caption: The white blaze marks the Appalachian Trail as a way for hikers to identify the route.

images.credit: Photo Credit: Maine Appalachian Trail Club
images.title: Volunteer on the A.T.
images.altText: A volunteer is carrying a split log while walking across a wooden footbridge in the woods.
images.caption: The Appalachian Trail is maintained largely by volunteers.

images.title: Winter on the A.T.
images.altText: A snowy winter view from the A.T. overlooking snowy mountains and clouds in the distance.
images.caption: Hikers can experience many seasons along the A.T. all year round. It is important to be prepared.

data.weatherInfo: It is your responsibility to be prepared for all weather conditions, including extreme and unexpected weather changes year-round. As the trail runs from Georgia to Maine there will be different weather conditions depending on your location. For weather along specific sections of the trail and at specific shelters, please refer to: http://www.atweather.org/
data.name: Appalachian

data.description: Today the river valley attracts us for so many reasons. Take a solitary walk to enjoy nature’s display, raft leisurely through the rocky shoals with friends, fish the misty waters as the sun comes up, or have a picnic on a Sunday afternoon. Get Outdoors and experience your Chattahoochee River National Recreation Area as you have never done before.

emailAddresses.description: Use this email address to contact the park. Once received your email will be directed to the appropriate person to assist you. If you should know the email address of the person you wish to contact please use it.

entranceFees.description: Required for visitors age 16+ entering on foot or by bicycle. Valid for one day.
entranceFees.title: Entrance - Per Person

entranceFees.description: Private vehicle pass admits one private vehicle and its occupants for one day.
entranceFees.title: Entrance - Private Vehicle

entranceFees.description: Valid for one motorcycle and its occupant(s) for one day.
entranceFees.title: Entrance - Motorcycle

entrancePasses.description: Frequent visitors may save money with an annual entrance pass. The park annual pass admits the cardholder and the other persons in a private vehicle to the park. You may purchase the pass online or in person at the Island Ford Visitor Center. America the Beautiful passes are also accepted.
entrancePasses.title: Annual Entrance - Park

data.directionsInfo: To find the Island Ford Visitor Center enter the physical address, 8800 Roberts Drive, Sandy Springs, GA 30350, into your GPS unit or your favorite map software. Once you have arrived at the park entrance turn onto Island Ford Parkway and follow the signs to the park headquarters.

operatingHours.description:
The park lands and waters are open for visitation from 30 minutes before sunrise to 30 minutes after sunset seven days a week.

The Island Ford Visitor Center located in historic Hewlett Lodge is open from 9 am to 5 pm seven days a week except Thanksgiving Day and December 25.
operatingHours.name: Park Hours

images.title: Family Time
images.altText: Two adult Great Blue Herons stand watch over their 3 young chicks in the nest.
images.caption: Great Blue Herons are plentyful along the river. Look towards the tree tops along the river to spot their nest. If you're lucky the whole will be home.

images.title: Look Closely
images.altText: Park ranger showing a group of school children the critter on his arm.
images.caption: School children from the city enjoy visiting the park on a ranger-led hike.

images.title: Marietta Paper Mill
images.altText: Stone ruins of the Marietta Paper Mill surrounded by lush green vegatation.
images.caption: All that is left of the Marietta Paper Mill is a few stone walls in the woods. Hike to the ruins and you'll get a closeup of Sope Creek that was harnessed by the mills.

images.title: Landing A Rainbow
images.altText: Angler in waders landing a fish using a landing net.
images.caption: Fishing the Chattahoochee River can be a great way to spend an afternoon out of the office or as a diversion from rush hour traffic.

images.title: Inviting Trail
images.altText: Trail heading off under a canopy of trees.
images.caption: Trails along the Chattahoochee River are calling you to visit.

data.weatherInfo: Summers typically consist of long spells of warm, humid weather. Average highs are in the lower 90's and overnight lows range from the upper 60's to lower 70's. Winters are more variable with highs averaging from the mid 50's to lower 60's while the lows average in the mid 30's. Oftentimes, stretches of mild weather will alternate with cold spells. Spring and Autumn seasons are characterized by much variability from day to day and from year to year.
data.name: Chattahoochee River

data.description: In 1863, Union and Confederate forces fought for control of Chattanooga, known as the "Gateway to the Deep South." The Confederates were victorious at nearby Chickamauga in September. However, renewed fighting in Chattanooga that November provided Union troops victory and control of the city. After the fighting, a Confederate soldier ominously wrote, "This...is the death-knell of the Confederacy."

entranceFees.description: Entrance fees only apply to Point Park, on Lookout Mountain. If you plan to visit Chickamauga Battlefield, parts of Lookout Mountain Battlefield, exclusive of Point Park, Missionary Ridge, Orchard Knob, Signal Point, or Moccasin Bend National Archeological District, entrance to the park areas is FREE.
entranceFees.title: Entrance - Per Person

entrancePasses.description: Annual Entrance Passes to Point Park allow the passholder and three additional adults to enter the park for free.
entrancePasses.title: Annual Entrance - Park

data.directionsInfo: From I-75, take exit 350 onto Battlefield Parkway (GA HWY 2) and continue to the intersection of Battlefield Parkway and LaFayette Road. Turn left onto LaFayette Road and continue for approximately 1 mile. The visitor center will be on the right. From I-24, take exit 180 onto Rossville Boulevard (US HWY 27). Continue south to the intersection of Battlefield Parkway. Drive through the intersection, continuing on the LaFayette Road. The visitor center will be on the right.

operatingHours.description: All units of Chickamauga and Chattanooga National Military Park are open during daylight hours, with the following exceptions: Chickamauga Battlefield Visitor Center and Lookout Mountain Battlefield Visitor Center are currently open 8:30 am to 5 pm, daily. Visitor centers are closed Dec. 25 and Jan. 1. Point Park main entrance opens at 8:30 am, daily. US Hwy 27 Picnic Area, Wilder Brigade Monument, & Signal Mountain restrooms are closed Dec.1 - March 15.
operatingHours.name: Chickamauga and Chattanooga National Military Park

images.title: Kelley Cabin on Chickamauga Battlefield
images.altText: Kelley Cabin
images.caption: Living Historians are seen in Kelley Field and in the distance at the Kelley Cabin during the 150th anniversary

images.title: Illinois Monument at Bragg Reservation on Missionary Ridge
images.altText: Illinois Monument
images.caption: Silent sentinels stand on the Illinois Monument at the Bragg Reservation on Missionary Ridge Battlefield

images.title: Cannon on Lookout Mountain
images.altText: Cannon on Lookout Mountain
images.caption: As the sun sets on Lookout Mountain, a lone cannon guards the valley below.

images.title: Lookout Mountain and the National Cemetery
images.altText: Lookout Mountain and the National Cemetery
images.caption: The graves of fallen soldiers from Chickamauga to present dot the landscape in Chattanooga as Lookout Mountain looms in the background

images.title: Living Historians on Orchard Knob in Chattanooga
images.altText: Living Historians on Orchard Knob
images.caption: Confederate soldiers stand watch from Orchard Knob during the 150th anniversary of the Battles for Chattanooga in 2013.

data.weatherInfo: The climate in northern Georgia is generally temperate. Short, cool winters give relief from hot summers. Most visitors enjoy this area during long, mild fall and spring seasons.
data.name: Chickamauga & Chattanooga

data.description: St Marys is the gateway to Cumberland Island, Georgia's largest and southernmost barrier island. Here pristine maritime forests, undeveloped beaches and wide marshes whisper the stories of both man and nature. Natives, missionaries, enslaved African Americans and Wealthy Industrialists all walked here. Cumberland Island is also home to over 9,800 acres of Congressionally designated Wilderness.

entranceFees.description: Cumberland Island National Seashore has a per-person entrance fee. This fee is waived for America the Beautiful pass holder plus three adults. Must present pass at time of check-in.
entranceFees.title: Entrance - Per Person

data.directionsInfo: Cumberland Island is only accessible by ferry or private boat. These directions are to the mainland visitor center in St. Marys, GA. Driving Directions To reach the visitor center from Interstate 95: •Take Exit 3 for US 40 •Take US 40 East toward “Historic Downtown St. Marys” •US 40 becomes Osborne Rd. Continue on until you reach the waterfront •Turn right on St. Marys Rd •The visitor center will be two blocks down on your left (113 St. Marys St W, St Marys GA 31558)

operatingHours.description: The park is open 24 hours a day, all year. The island is only accessible by boat. The visitor center, other facilities, ferry operations, and docks for private boats all have separate hours, however; please see descriptions of those facilities elsewhere.
operatingHours.name: Cumberland Island National Seashore

images.title: Vegetated Dunes
images.altText: Sand dunes covered with shrubs and grasses
images.caption: Vegetation holds dunes in place providing a barrier to erosion forces and creating essential interdune meadows to support island life.

images.title: Home To Wildlife
images.altText: Alligator resting on a log in pond
images.caption: Cumberland Island National Seashore encompasses a variety of forest, marsh, and coastal landscapes providing a home for numerous species including American Alligators.

images.title: Undeveloped Coast
images.altText: Ocean beach at sunrise
images.caption: Cumberland Island National Seashore encompasses nearly 18 miles of undeveloped beach offering recreation for visitors and essential nesting area for birds and sea turtles.

images.title: Plum Orchard Mansion
images.altText: large, white mansion behind oak trees draped with Spanish Moss
images.caption: Visitors can take a guided tour of the Plum Orchard Mansion and experience the luxuries of Victorian high society as well as the effort and ingenuity it took to make it possible.

images.title: Island Bluffs Shaped By Tides
images.altText: rippled sands of a beach in front of pine tree covered bluffs
images.caption: Tidal forces continue to shape the land today as they have for thousands of years forming high bluffs used for fortifications and ship docking throughout the island’s history.

images.title: Historic Main Road
images.altText: huge oak trees and palm shrubs line a sand road
images.caption: While visitors to the island cannot bring vehicles, they can travel the historic main park road by foot and bicycle. Some remaining island residents will still drive vehicles on the road to reach their residences as they have for generations.

images.title: Dungeness Ruins
images.altText: brick and stone ruins of a large mansion at sunset under colorful clouds
images.caption: Dugeness was the largest mansion built on the island as part of the Carnegie Estate. Though lost to fire in 1959, the ruins of the mansion and several of its support structures are a reminder of the island’s rich history.

images.title: The Settlement
images.altText: small white one room church, old red house in the background, under cloudy skies
images.caption: The remote north end of the island is home to the First African Baptist Church and The Settlement, where African American residents were able to purchase their first deeded property on the island at the end of the 1800s.

images.title: Tidal Creek
images.altText: tidal creek at low tide surrounded by palm and oak trees
images.caption: Rising tides bring valuable nutrients into tidal creeks, while receding tides remove waste. This makes the tide cycle the beating heart of the island’s tidal creeks, salt marshes, and estuaries.

data.weatherInfo: Cumberland Island’s climate is hot and humid during summer when temperatures tend to be in the 80's (>26 C) and mild during winter when temperatures tend to be in the 60's (<20 C). The warmest month of the year is July with an average high of 90 degrees F (32 C), while the coldest is January with an average low of 45 degrees F (44 C). Visit the Current Conditions page for an up-to-date local forecast: https://www.nps.gov/cuis/planyourvisit/conditions.htm#weather
data.name: Cumberland Island

data.description: War was imminent as James Oglethorpe established Fort Frederica in 1736, to help protect the British colonies from the Spanish in Florida. Fort Frederica illustrates the story of the War of Jenkins Ear (1739-1748) and how its British defenders fought off the Spanish Army. Today, archeology has uncovered the story of the 1,000 people that once lived here.
data.directionsInfo: Directions from Torras Causeway: at end of causeway, get in left lane. Follow left lane to traffic light. Go straight at light. Follow Sea Island Road to Frederica Road. Turn left at traffic light onto Frederica Road. Follow Frederica to roundabout. Take second exit of roundabout (still on Frederica). Go approximately 1 mile. Turn left onto park entrance road. Across from Wesley United Methodist Church. For detailed directions, clink the link below.

operatingHours.description:
Park & Grounds Closed:

Thanksgiving
Christmas Day
New Year's Day
operatingHours.name: Fort Frederica National Monument Grounds

operatingHours.description: Bloody Marsh is roughly where the site of the last battle of the Spanish invasion of Georgia took place on July 7th. Though casualties were relatively light, it would rob the Spanish of their enthusiasm and lead to their abandonment of their campaign. Located 7 miles south from the front gates of the town of Frederica, this relatively minor engagement ended the Spanish threat to the Georgia colonies.
operatingHours.name: Bloody Marsh Site

operatingHours.description: The Visitor Center is closed Monday and Tuesday. The park grounds remain open for visitation.
operatingHours.name: Visitor Center Hours

images.title: Ruin of Soldier Barracks at Fort Frederica NM
images.altText: Ruin of Soldier Barracks at Fort Frederica NM
images.caption: The Barracks ruin is one of the few above ground structures at Fort Frederica

images.caption: Artist rendering of Downtown Frederica Town

images.caption: Artifacts found at Frederica

images.title: Soldiers of the 42nd Regiment of Foote
images.altText: Reenactors performing as the original redcoats who served at Frederica

images.title: 100 year old grapevine at Frederica
images.altText: A large grapevine draped among the Live Oaks
images.caption: 100 year old grapevine at Frederica which still produces "Summer Grapes"

images.title: Fort Frederica at Sunset
images.altText: The shadow of the ruin of Fort Frederica highlighted by a sunset along the Frederica River.
images.caption: Nature and History combine in a beautiful setting at Fort Frederica

images.title: Fort Frederica's Visitor Center during Azalea Season
images.altText: Brick building of the Visitor Center with Azaleas blossoming in front
images.caption: Fort Frederica's Visitor Center during Azalea Season

data.weatherInfo: The site enjoys mild climate from fall through early summer, followed by hot, humid summers.
data.name: Fort Frederica

data.description: For much of the 19th century, masonry fortifications were the United States’ main defense against overseas enemies. However, during the Civil War, new technology proved its superiority over these forts. Using rifled cannons, the U.S. Army compelled the Confederate garrison inside Fort Pulaski to surrender. The siege was a landmark experiment in the history of military science and invention.

entranceFees.description: A per person fee of $10 is required to visit Fort Pulaski and the surrounding areas. Admission is valid for 7 consecutive days. Youth 15 and under are admitted free of charge. Only available at the entrance station to Fort Pulaski National Monument. Credit/Debit Only
entranceFees.title: Entrance - Per Person

entranceFees.description: Commercial bus/van tours are charged the per person fee for the number of persons on board.
entranceFees.title: Commercial Entrance - Per Person

entrancePasses.description: The Fort Pulaski Annual Park Pass provides entry into Fort Pulaski National Monument for the pass holder and 3 other adults. The pass is valid for a year from the month of purchase. Each Fort Pulaski Annual Park Pass comes with one signature line for a single passholder.
entrancePasses.title: Annual Entrance - Park

data.directionsInfo: From Interstate I-95, take Exit 99 onto Interstate I-16 East (James L Gillis Memorial Hwy) for 7 miles. Take Exit 164A onto Interstate I-516 East toward US-80 East. Take Exit 3 (US-17 S/US-80 E) toward US-80 East. Turn left onto Ocean Highway, Ogeechee Rd (US-17 N, US-80 East). Bear right onto West Victory Drive (US-80 East). Continue on US-80 East for 13 miles. GPS Coordinates for Fort Pulaski National Monument: N32° 01.680 W080° 53.525

operatingHours.description: Fort Pulaski National Monument is open year round from 9:00 a.m. to 5:00 pm, except for New Years, Thanksgiving, and Christmas Days. Last entry into the park is at 4:30 pm. Historic Fort Pulaski is open 9:00 a.m. to 4:30 pm and the Visitor Center is open from 9:00 am to 5:00 pm.
operatingHours.name: Fort Pulaski National Monument

operatingHours.description: Historic Fort Pulaski is open from 9:00am to 4:30pm, every day.
operatingHours.name: Historic Fort Pulaski

operatingHours.description: Last entry to the park is at 4:30pm.
operatingHours.name: Entrance Station

images.title: The Battered Walls of Fort Pulaski
images.altText: The red masonry walls of Fort Pulaski still show battle damage over 150 years later.
images.caption: A walk along the outside of Fort Pulaski reveals damaged walls over 150 years after the Civil War.

images.title: The Casemates of a Fort
images.altText: The brick of the fort glow in the late afternoon light. The arches inside the fort reveal a cannon i
images.caption: Fort Pulaski shows off its classic arched architecture and cannon.

images.title: The Cockspur Island Lighthouse
images.altText: The white masonry Cockspur Island lighthouse sits in the Savannah River.
images.caption: The Cockspur Island Lighthouse still stands guard over the south channel of the Savannah River and Fort Pulaski.

images.title: The Sentinel
images.altText: A great blue heron stands watch on top of the fort's brick walls.
images.caption: A great blue heron stands on the top of Fort Pulaski like a lonely sentinel.

images.title: The Ladies of a Fort
images.altText: Two women dressed in mid nineteenth century civilian attire watch through looking glasses
images.caption: Volunteer living historians play an important role for the National Park Service and Fort Pulaski National Monument.

images.title: Night Cannon Firing at Fort Pulaski
images.altText: The night sky is illuminated as a cannon fires at Fort Pulaski
images.caption: Artillery demonstrations are an important part of the interpretation program at Fort Pulaski.

data.weatherInfo: Savannah has a humid sub tropical climate with over two hundred days of sunshine each year. Summers are typically hot, bright and humid with afternoon thunderstorms common. Temperatures often range from the lower 70s to the mid 90s F. Spring and autumn can be quite pleasant with temperatures ranging from the upper 50s into the 80s F. The winter months are usually dry. Temperatures can be cooler than one would expect, ranging from the upper 30s through the 60s F generally, though sudden cold snaps can occur.
data.name: Fort Pulaski

data.description: Few U.S. Presidents have had such close ties with where they were born and raised. The rural southern culture of Plains, Georgia revolves around farming, church, and school, which had a large influence in molding the character and shaping the political policies of the 39th President of the United States.

emailAddresses.description: The main email contact for the Jimmy Carter National Historical Park.

data.directionsInfo: In Americus take US 280W/ W Forsyth St. until it becomes US-19 S/US-280 W/S Martin Luther King Blvd. Turn left and go .08 mile. Turn right onto US-280 W and travel 8.9 miles. Turn right onto North Bond Street/ Hwy 45 North. Plains High School Visitor Center and Museum will be on the right side of the road 500 feet from the intersection.

operatingHours.description: Plains Depot was chosen for President Carter's 1976 Presidential Campaign Headquarters because it was vacant and it had a public restroom. Today the building is a museum for Jimmy Carter's campaign for Georgia State Senate, Governor of Georgia, and President of the United States.
operatingHours.name: Plains Depot

operatingHours.description: Jimmy Carter's father, Earl Carter, moved the family to the community of Archery, Georgia when Jimmy Carter was 4 years old. He lived here until he went off to college. In 2000, the National Park Service opened up a restored Jimmy Carter Boyhood Farm to the public.
operatingHours.name: Jimmy Carter Boyhood Farm

operatingHours.description: Jimmy Carter National Historical Park provides visitors with an opportunity to explore the lasting impact of President Jimmy Carter and First Lady Rosalynn Carter, including their final resting place.
operatingHours.name: Carter Gardens

images.title: Jimmy Carter's Boyhood Home
images.altText: A picture of the front of the home Jimmy Carter lived in as a young boy.
images.caption: Front view of the Jimmy Carter Boyhood Home in Archery, Georgia.

images.title: Plains High School Museum and Visitors Center
images.altText: Front view of Plains High School Visitor Center and Museum
images.caption: Almost one hundred thousand visitors visit Plains High School Visitor Center and Museum yearly.

images.title: Plains Depot, 1976 Campaign Headquarters
images.altText: The Plains train depot that President Carter used as the 1976 campaign headquarters.
images.caption: The oldest building in Plains, the train depot, was used as the 1976 campaign headquarters for President Carter.

images.title: Jimmy Carter Presidents' Day 2016
images.altText: Jimmy Carter speaking to the crowd; Presidents' Day 2016
images.caption: President Jimmy Carter speaking to the crowd at Plains High School for Presidents' Day 2016

images.title: Rosalynn Carter, Presidents' Day 2016
images.altText: Rosalynn Carter signing a book, Presidents' Day 2016
images.caption: Rosalynn Carter signing a book she authored during Presidents' Day 2016

data.weatherInfo: When visiting Southwest Georgia during the summer, expect hot and humid weather with the potential for thunderstorms. Check the local forecast before planning any outdoor activities in the region and be prepared with appropriate clothing, sun protection, and hydration to ensure a comfortable and safe visit.
data.name: Jimmy Carter

data.description: Kennesaw Mountain National Battlefield Park is a 2,965 acre National Battlefield that preserves a Civil War battleground of the Atlanta Campaign. Opposing forces maneuvered and fought here from June 19, 1864 until July 2, 1864. Although most famous as a Civil War battlefield, Kennesaw Mountain has a much richer story.

entranceFees.description: The Daily Pass is valid for the date of purchase only. It admits all persons traveling in a single, private, non-commercial vehicle (car/truck/van) and is non-transferable. This pass does NOT guarantee a parking spot.
entranceFees.title: Entrance - Private Vehicle

entranceFees.description: The Daily Pass is valid for the date of purchase only. It admits all walk-in visitors aged 16 and older.
entranceFees.title: Entrance - Per Person

entranceFees.description: To request an Academic Fee Waiver for your group, click on the link for further details.
entranceFees.title: Entrance - Education/Academic Groups

entranceFees.description: $100 Motor Coach/Commercial Tour Groups with 26 or more people
entranceFees.title: Commercial Entrance - Motor Coach

entrancePasses.description: The Annual Pass is valid for one year from the month of purchase. It admits all persons traveling in a single, private, non-commercial vehicle (car/truck/van) and is non-transferable. This pass does NOT guarantee a parking spot upon arrival.  This can be purchased online, in our Visitor Center, or at any of our 5 Automated Fee Machines located in our major parking lots. A valid debit/credit card will be needed as none of these locations accept cash.
entrancePasses.title: Annual Entrance - Park

data.directionsInfo: Kennesaw Mountain NBP is fairly spread out with multiple parking lots. Many visitors begin their visit at the Visitor Center located at 900 Kennesaw Mountain Dr. and orient themselves to the park with Ranger or Volunteer. For more detailed directions, please see link below.

operatingHours.description:
Kennesaw Mountain NBP is open from 6:30 AM - 8:30 PM during Daylight Saving Time (March - November) and 6:30 AM - 6:30 PM Standard Time (December - February) 

These hours apply to all trails and parking lots.*
*Cheatham Hill Parking Lot opens at 8:00 am
operatingHours.name: Kennesaw Mountain National Battlefield Park

operatingHours.description: This parking lot is located off of Dallas Highway and Cheatham Hill Dr.
operatingHours.name: Cheatham Hill Parking Lot

data.weatherInfo: Before you start your trip to the mountain, check the local weather forecast to be sure that you will have a dry time. Though we are located north of Atlanta, we're still have the same hot summers and mild winters as our neighbors. The mountain top generally ranges 8-10 degrees cooler than at the base. In fall and winter, be prepared with a light weight jacket on hand. After planning your activities, check back to see what the weather will have in store for your day.
data.name: Kennesaw Mountain

data.fullName: Martin Luther King, Jr. National Historical Park
data.description: Welcome to Martin Luther King, Jr. National Historical Park & Preservation District where a young boy grows up in a time of segregation. He was moved by destiny to lead the modern civil rights movement. This was Martin Luther King, Jr. Explore his roots, walk in his footsteps, visit the home of his birth, and where he played as a child. Hear his voice in the church where he changed the world.
data.directionsInfo: The park is accessible via public transportation and by car.

operatingHours.description:
Access to buildings at the Martin Luther King, Jr. National Historical Park is as follows:

Open: Monday – Sunday, 9:00am – 5:00pm

Visitor Center 
Historic Ebenezer Baptist Church 
Birth Home – Tours are temporarily on-hold. 
Fire Station No. 6 – Opened with staff availability.
operatingHours.name: Martin Luther King, Jr. National Historical Park

images.altText: Visitor center and the "I Have a Dream" Internrational World Peace Rose
images.caption: The visitor center features an exhibit entitled "Courage To Lead".

images.altText: The Birth Home of Martin Luther King, Jr.
images.caption: The Birth Home of Martin Luther King, Jr.

images.title: Historic Ebenezer Baptist Church
images.altText: Historic Ebenezer Baptist Church
images.caption: The spiritual home of the King Family.

images.title: Fire Station No. 6
images.altText: Fire Station No. 6
images.caption: The second Fire Station integrated in the City of Atlanta.

images.title: The Tomb of Dr. and Mrs. Martin Luther King, Jr.
images.altText: The Tomb of Dr. and Mrs. Martin Luther King, Jr.
images.caption: The Tomb of Dr. and Mrs. Martin Luther King, Jr.  rests on a brick island within a reflecting pool.

data.weatherInfo: Summers typically are warm and humid with average afternoon high temperatures are in the lower 90s. During winter the high temperatures average from the mid-50s to the lower 60s. Lows average in the mid-30s. Spring and Autumn seasons are characterized by much variability from day to day and from year to year. The average date of first freeze is in mid-November and the date of the last freeze is mid to late March.
data.name: Martin Luther King, Jr.

data.description: Welcome to Ocmulgee Mounds National Historical Park. This park is a prehistoric American Indian site, where many different American Indian cultures occupied this land for thousands of years. American Indians first came here during the Paleo-Indian Period hunting Ice Age mammals. Around 900 CE, the Mississippian Period began, and people constructed mounds for their elite, which remain here today.
data.directionsInfo: The park is located in East Macon, along Emery Highway. Enter the park address, 1207 Emery Highway, Macon, GA 31217 to get directions to the site.

operatingHours.description:
Ocmulgee Mounds National Historical Park   

Park grounds and walking trails are open from 8:00 am to 5:00 pm daily.

The Visitor Center and Earth Lodge are open from 9:00 am-5:00 pm daily.
operatingHours.name: Ocmulgee Mounds National Historical Park & Visitor Center

images.title: Great Temple and Lesser Temple Mound
images.altText: mounds
images.caption: The Great Temple Mound is the largest mound at the park, it stands at 55 feet tall.

images.title: Earth Lodge
images.altText: earth lodge
images.caption: The Earth Lodge was used as a council chamber for the Mississippian Culture (900-1600)

images.title: Earth Lodge Floor
images.altText: earth lodge floor
images.caption: The earth Lodge floor is original it was carbon dated to 1015.

images.title: The Funeral Mound
images.altText: funeral mound
images.caption: The Funeral Mound was by prehistoric cultures to bury their dead. Today there are still remains instead the mound

images.title: Clovis Point
images.altText: spear point
images.caption: This Clovis point is the first spear found east of the Mississippi River. It was carbon dated to 10,000 BC

data.weatherInfo: Macon has a humid subtropical climate (Köppen climate classification Cfa). The average high temperature ranges from 46 to 58°F (7.7 to 14.4°C) in January and 82 to 91°F (27.7 to 32.7°C) in July. Winters are mild. Temps ranging from 30 degrees to 50 degrees. Spring is mild but wet. Temps ranging from 50 degrees to low 70 degrees. Summers are hot and very humid. Temp ranging from upper 80 degrees to 100 degrees. Fall is pleasant. Temps ranging from 60 to 80 degrees.
data.name: Ocmulgee Mounds

data.fullName: Trail Of Tears National Historic Trail
data.description: Remember and commemorate the survival of the Cherokee people, forcefully removed from their homelands in Georgia, Alabama, and Tennessee to live in Indian Territory, now Oklahoma. They traveled by foot, horse, wagon, or steamboat in 1838-1839.
data.directionsInfo: You can visit many of the sites along the Trail of Tears National Historic Trail over the 2,200+ mile route that crosses 9 states.

operatingHours.description: OPERATING HOURS VARY FROM SITE TO SITE. There are many historic sites, museums, and parks (federal, state, and local) along the Trail of Tears in Tennessee, North Carolina, Georgia, Alabama, Kentucky, Illinois, Arkansas, Missouri, or Oklahoma for you to visit. Please contact individual sites for more information by going to Plan Your Visit and selecting Places To Go or Passport Program, where sites are listed by state, and there is an interactive map to search for sites.
operatingHours.name: Trail of Tears National Historic Trail

addresses.line2: Trail of Tears National Historic Trail
Trail of Tears National Historic Trail

images.title: Chieftain's Museum, Rome, Georgia
images.altText: large white house, green lawn, two trees in front
images.caption: The museum tells the story of Major Ridge, the influential Ridge family including prominent son John Ridge, Cherokee history, and the Trail of Tears, as well as subsequent history of the home and region.

images.title: Brown's Ferry Tavern, Chattanooga, Tennessee
images.altText: structure in the background with large chimney on the end; signs saying Brown's Ferry Tavern
images.caption: Cherokee leader John Brown, who owned 640 acres in this area, ordered the construction of Browns Ferry Tavern in 1803. In 1838, the road running past this structure was the route by which several Cherokee detachments were removed to present-day Oklahoma.

images.title: Mantle Rock Preserve, Joy, Kentucky
images.altText: sunlight coming through trees with green leaves
images.caption: Thousands of Cherokee camped for weeks along the main (northern) route, near Mantle Rock, during the winter of 1838-39 as they waited for ice conditions in the Ohio River to allow a safe crossing.

images.title: Cherokee Retracement at Pea Ridge National Military Park, Garfield, Arkansas
images.altText: dozens of people walk a section of the Trail of Tears, winter scene, trees with no leaves
images.caption: The Pea Ridge National Military Park encompasses 4,300 acres and features a visitor center, museum, self-guided tours, reconstructed Elkhorn Tavern, and a retracement trail along a 2.5-mile original route segment of the Trail of Tears.

images.title: Grave Stone of William Adair, Stilwell, Oklahoma
images.altText: gravestone with words etched, green grass
images.caption: When the Cherokee arrived at their prescribed disbandment depot in Oklahoma, settlements sprang up nearby. There was a depot at the Adair's farm near present-day Stilwell, Oklahoma.

images.title: Crabb Abbott Farm, Grantsburg, Illinois
images.altText: Two people walk a remnant of the Trail of Tears. Spring setting with green leafed trees.
images.caption: Crabb Abbott Farm has segments of the Northern Route, including the rock crossing and ford of Sugar Creek. These segments are contiguous with trail segments on the adjacent Shawnee National Forest.

data.weatherInfo: Due to the length of the Trail of Tears National Historic Trail, be sure to consult local weather sources for the region you'll be visiting. Check out the forecast with the National Weather Service and search for the area you'd like to visit: www.weather.gov
data.name: Trail Of Tears
